result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

10:04 AM Prosecuting attorney Jennifer C Zima in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Jason R Schultz in court.  Attorney Aaron Thomas Vruwink in court for Jason R Schultz. 

Atty Vruwink moves to withdraw due to a conflict.  Court grants.

records.descr: Pet for appointment counsel,affidavit of indigency

records.addlTxt: 10:50:AM  Defendnat Jason Schultz appears, Attorney Jennifer Zima appears for the State Wisconsin  Court questions the defendant regarding obtaining an attorney.  Defendant states he is not eligible for a public defender and Court explains applying for a court appointed attorney.  Officer Aaron Anderson is sworn as witness and testifies to the facts.  Testifies to a follow up visit regarding a previous welfare check regarding the defendants children.  Testifies to the follow up visit and search of the defendants home.  Testifies to substances found, test of those substance and results.  Testifies to what the mother of the children said she seen at the home.  Probable cause found. Bond continued
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment on April 1, 2022 at 10:45 am.
